name: The Churchill Arms
description: Famous for its exuberant floral displays and often called London’s most colourful pub​:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}, this 18th-century Kensington pub also claims to be the first in London to serve Thai food in-house.

name: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese
description: Rebuilt in 1667 after the Great Fire of London, this labyrinthine Fleet Street tavern is known for its literary associations – regulars included Charles Dickens, Mark Twain and others​:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

name: Prospect of Whitby
description: A historic riverside tavern dating back to around 1520​:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}, celebrated as London’s oldest riverside pub. It still boasts a 400-year-old stone floor and was once a notorious haunt for sailors and smugglers​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

name: The Mayflower
description: Historic 16th-century pub in Rotherhithe – often cited as the oldest pub on the River Thames​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}. It features a decked jetty overlooking the site of the Mayflower ship’s 1620 mooring point​:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}, honoring its Pilgrim heritage.

name: The Anchor, Bankside
description: Rebuilt in 1676, The Anchor is the sole surviving riverside tavern from Shakespeare’s era on Bankside​:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}. Samuel Pepys is said to have watched the Great Fire of 1666 from an earlier pub on this site, and it remains a popular stop with its riverside terrace.

name: The George Inn
description: London’s last remaining galleried coaching inn​:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}, dating from 1676. This Southwark landmark has a cobbled courtyard and oak-beamed galleries – Charles Dickens was among its notable patrons, even mentioning it in "Little Dorrit."

name: Ye Olde Mitre
description: A tucked-away historic pub founded in 1546 (rebuilt in 1773) down a Hatton Garden alley. It’s famously associated with a legend that Queen Elizabeth I once danced around a cherry tree here with Sir Christopher Hatton​:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

name: Lamb & Flag
description: A 300-year-old Covent Garden pub once nicknamed “The Bucket of Blood” for its bare-knuckle prize fights​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. In 1679 the poet John Dryden was famously beaten in the alley beside this pub​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10} – today it’s much more peaceful!

name: Spaniards Inn
description: A historic inn on the edge of Hampstead Heath dating back to 1585​:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. Legend has it the highwayman Dick Turpin was a regular (and his ghost supposedly haunts the pub)​:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. It offers a large beer garden and a cozy, fire-lit interior.

name: The Ten Bells
description: An infamous Spitalfields pub that has stood (in one form or another) since the mid-18th century​:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. It’s noted for its Victorian tiled interior and its proximity to the Jack the Ripper story – two of his victims were said to frequent this pub.

name: The French House
description: Bohemian Soho pub famous as a wartime meeting place for Charles de Gaulle and the Free French in WWII​:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}. It’s known for its no music or TV rule and serves beer only in half-pint measures, fostering good conversation in its intimate space.

name: The Grapes
description: A tiny 16th-century pub on the Limehouse Thames waterfront – there’s been a pub here for nearly 500 years​:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}. Charles Dickens drank here (and immortalized it as the "Six Jolly Fellowship Porters" in *Our Mutual Friend*​:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}). Now co-owned by actor Sir Ian McKellen, it retains an old-world charm.

name: The Dove
description: A  eighteenth-century riverside pub in Hammersmith famous for its extremely small bar (once listed by Guinness as the smallest public bar). Literary figures like Ernest Hemingway and Graham Greene have been among its patrons​:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}, and it offers a tranquil terrace overlooking the Thames.

name: The Blind Beggar
description: This Whitechapel pub is notorious for its connection to East End gangsters the Kray twins – Ronnie Kray infamously shot and killed rival George Cornell here in March 1966​:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. It’s also the pub where William Booth began the work that led to founding the Salvation Army in 1865.

name: The Eagle, City Road
description: A Victorian pub in Clerkenwell immortalized in the nursery rhyme “Pop Goes the Weasel” – “Up and down the City Road, in and out the Eagle” is a line still proudly displayed on its sign​:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}. Today it’s a family-friendly pub known for its real ales and Sunday roasts.

name: The Old Bank of England
description: A grand pub on Fleet Street occupying the former Bank of England law courts branch (built 1888)​:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}. Its interior features majestic high ceilings, chandeliers, and a rich Victorian décor – the pub’s vaults supposedly once held gold bullion and even the Crown Jewels​:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}!

name: Viaduct Tavern
description: One of London’s few remaining Victorian gin palaces (established 1869). This ornate Holborn pub features etched glass and mahogany interiors – and rumor has it that in its cellars lie remnants of Newgate Prison cells from across the road​:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}, adding to its mystique.

name: Trafalgar Tavern
description: A large Grade II listed pub opened in 1837 on Greenwich’s riverbank. In Victorian times it was famous for whitebait dinners attended by politicians and even Prime Ministers​:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}. With its elegant Regency-style rooms and river views, it remains a Greenwich centerpiece of maritime charm.

name: The Star Tavern
description: A 19th-century mews pub in Belgravia that was once a secret haunt of London’s elite and unsavory alike – the Great Train Robbery of 1963 was planned within its walls​:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}. Despite its scandalous past (and legendary parties upstairs), today it’s a relaxed Fuller’s pub with a cozy atmosphere.

name: The Grenadier
description: A tiny 18th-century pub hidden in a Belgravia cobbled mews (once an officers’ mess hall). The Grenadier is steeped in lore – it’s said to be haunted by the ghost of a young soldier, and its ceiling is plastered with banknotes left by visitors to pay off the phantom debt. Despite the spooky fame, it’s a charming spot for a pint by the fire.

name: The Dog & Bull
description: An 18th-century Grade II listed pub in Croydon, known for its historic charm and vibrant beer garden.

name: The Dog & Bull
description: An 18th-century Grade II listed pub in Croydon, known for its historic charm and vibrant beer garden.

name: The Hare & Billet
description: A Blackheath pub surrounded by green spaces, perfect for relaxing after a walk around Blackheath Common or Greenwich Park.

name: The Duke of Edinburgh
description: A popular Brixton pub boasting a massive beer garden, ideal for lively gatherings.

name: The Dolphin
description: A Sydenham pub with a striking 1930s mock-Tudor exterior and a spacious, manicured beer garden.

name: The White Hart
description: A Barnes pub offering amazing views of the river from its beer garden.

name: The Ship
description: A Wandsworth pub known for its riverside location and lively atmosphere.

name: The Prince
description: Located in West Brompton, this pub offers a large beer garden and a variety of food options.

name: The Anchor
description: A Wisley pub with a picturesque setting and a welcoming atmosphere.

name: The Fox & Firkin
description: A lively Lewisham pub known for its live music events and spacious beer garden.

name: The Crown & Greyhound
description: A historic pub in Dulwich Village, affectionately known as 'The Dog', offering a cozy atmosphere and a lovely beer garden.

name: The Bedford
description: A Balham pub renowned for its live music, comedy nights, and spacious interiors.

name: The Camberwell Arms
description: A Camberwell pub celebrated for its exceptional food menu and relaxed ambiance.

name: The Ivy House
description: A community-owned pub in Nunhead, offering live music, theater, and a welcoming environment.

name: The Old Brewery
description: Located in Greenwich, this pub offers a unique setting within the historic Old Royal Naval College.

name: The Black Lion
description: Established in 1898, this Kilburn pub boasts preserved copper relief panels and a richly decorated interior, offering a glimpse into Victorian-era design.

name: The Boleyn Tavern
description: Opened in 1900, this East Ham pub features seven distinct drinking spaces around a central bar, with a notable billiards room illuminated by a colored-glass skylight.

name: The Cittie of Yorke
description: A Sam Smith's pub rebuilt in the 1920s to evoke Olde England, featuring a grand timber hall, a lengthy bar, and enclosed booths, reminiscent of historic London taverns.

name: The Coach and Horses
description: A Soho institution known for its association with journalist Jeffrey Bernard and former landlord Norman Balon, often dubbed 'London's rudest landlord.'

name: The Audley Public House
description: Located in Mayfair, this pub combines traditional charm with contemporary art, offering patrons a unique blend of classic pub atmosphere and modern aesthetics.

name: The Newman Arms
description: A Fitzrovia pub dating back to 1730, known for its unpretentious atmosphere, serving Truman's real ales and renowned for its handmade pies.

name: The Guinea Grill
description: Situated in Mayfair, this pub has been serving patrons for centuries, featuring a classic front bar and the renowned Guinea Grill, famous for top-class Aberdeen Angus beef.

name: Jamaica Wine House
description: Nestled in The City, this pub is known for its historical significance as London's first coffee house, now serving as a traditional pub with a rich past.

name: The Princess Louise
description: Located in Holborn, this pub is celebrated for its well-preserved Victorian interior, featuring wood paneling and ornate glasswork, offering a glimpse into 19th-century pub design.

name: The Cross Keys
description: A Chelsea pub adorned with an eclectic collection of memorabilia, offering a cozy atmosphere and a rich history dating back to the 18th century.

name: The Jerusalem Tavern
description: Situated in Clerkenwell, this pub occupies a building dating back to the 14th century, offering a unique historical ambiance alongside a selection of St. Peter's Brewery ales.

name: The Lamb
description: Located in Bloomsbury, this pub is known for its preserved Victorian features, including 'snob screens' and etched glass, creating a classic London pub experience.

name: The Rye
description: A spacious pub with a large beer garden, perfect for summer days. It's dog-friendly and offers a relaxed atmosphere.

name: Prince of Peckham
description: A vibrant pub known for its Caribbean-inspired menu, live music events, and a welcoming environment. It's dog-friendly and has a cozy beer garden.

name: The White Horse
description: A classic British pub offering a selection of ales and a spacious beer garden. It's dog-friendly and often features live music.

name: The Montpelier
description: A cozy pub known for its intimate atmosphere, delicious food, and a small cinema room. It's dog-friendly and has a beer garden.

name: The Gowlett
description: A local favorite, this pub is known for its wood-fired pizzas, friendly atmosphere, and live music. It has a beer garden and is dog-friendly.

name: The Angel Oak
description: A historic pub offering a buzzing garden, live sports, and a dog-friendly environment. It's a great spot to catch a game or enjoy a meal in the garden.

name: The Victoria Inn
description: A stylish pub with boutique hotel rooms, offering a range of craft beers and a modern British menu. It's dog-friendly and has a small beer garden.

name: The Nags Head
description: A traditional Irish pub known for its lively atmosphere, live music sessions, and friendly locals. It's dog-friendly and has a beer garden.

name: The Kentish Drovers
description: A spacious pub offering a wide selection of drinks and affordable meals. It has a beer garden and shows major sports events.

name: The Copper Tap
description: A modern pub with a rustic feel, offering craft beers, artisan spirits, and a menu of classic pub dishes. It's dog-friendly and has outdoor seating.

name: The Bussey Rooftop Bar
description: Located atop the Bussey Building, this rooftop bar offers panoramic views of London, a selection of cocktails, and wood-fired pizzas. It's a popular summer spot.

name: The Prince Albert
description: A community-focused pub known for its friendly atmosphere, quiz nights, and live music. It has a beer garden and is dog-friendly.

name: The Dog and Duck
description: A historic Victorian pub famously frequented by George Orwell. Known for ornate interiors and traditional ales.

name: The French House
description: Legendary bohemian Soho pub where Charles de Gaulle wrote speeches. Only serves half-pints.

name: The Crown & Two Chairmen
description: Stylish Soho pub serving craft beers and gastropub food with small outdoor seating.

name: The Coach & Horses
description: Soho’s ‘infamous’ pub, once home to ‘London’s rudest landlord’. Known for Private Eye regulars.

name: The Ship
description: Lively, traditional Soho pub popular with locals and musicians. Dog-friendly with real ales.

name: The John Snow
description: Named after the doctor who stopped Soho's cholera outbreak. Historic pub with real ales.

name: The Blue Posts
description: Classic Soho pub with mahogany interiors, real ales, and a hidden cocktail bar upstairs.

name: The Lyric
description: Charming Victorian corner pub with a great craft beer selection near Piccadilly Circus.

name: The George
description: Cozy historic pub with exposed beams, a roaring fire, and a fine whiskey collection.

name: The Sun & 13 Cantons
description: Soho favorite with rotating pop-up kitchens, craft beers, and indie film history.

name: The Duke of Wellington
description: Popular LGBTQ+ pub in Soho with drag nights, friendly staff, and classic pub vibes.

name: The Spice of Life
description: Iconic Soho music pub, once hosting Dylan and Bowie. Now a classic ale and music spot.

name: The Cambridge
description: Large corner pub opposite Palace Theatre with traditional decor and cask ales.

name: The Angel
description: Victorian-era Nicholson’s pub with classic London charm and real ales.

name: The Queen's Head
description: Boutique craft beer pub tucked behind Shaftesbury Avenue with a quirky, friendly vibe.

name: The King's Arms
description: Traditional Soho gay pub known for Sunday roasts, cask ales, and good vibes.

name: The Cock Tavern
description: Vibrant Soho pub known for its loud atmosphere, sports, and traditional pub layout.

name: Slug and Lettuce Soho
description: Chain bar with cocktails, food, and a lively atmosphere. Occasional sports shown.

name: The Yard
description: Gay-friendly bar with an open courtyard, popular with Soho crowds for outdoor drinks.

name: The Old Coffee House
description: Traditional pub serving Brodie’s beers brewed in London with old-school interiors.
